Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC: Wind Energy, Science, Technology, and Research (WindSTAR)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The I/UCRC for Wind Energy Science, Technology and Research plans to integrate engineering with fundamental research to support the development of wind energy systems for production of low-cost energy with high reliability. The center and its partners intend to engage in a cooperative program of research and education in the following key areas: (a) Composites, (b) Foundations, Towers, and Infrastructure (c) Manufacturing and Design, (d) Structural Health Monitoring, Non-Destructive Inspection, and Testing, (e) Control Systems and Energy Storage, and (f) Wind System Planning, Siting, and Operations.

The proposed I/UCRC will have broad impacts with respect to the environment, the economy, and education. With large minority populations near Lowell and Dallas, the Center is well situated to involve underrepresented groups within the wind energy field. The Center intends to leverage best practices from several successful programs to develop and integrate educational activities that enhance recruitment and retention of diverse student populations and encourage under-represented minority and female students to pursue STEM careers. In addition to workforce development and R&D, WindSTAR will provide a forum in which multiple facets of the wind industry (e.g., wind turbine manufacturers, manufacturers of key components, materials suppliers, suppliers of ancillary equipment, service companies, and wind project developers) can work together to solve precompetitive problems that hinder the advancement of wind energy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Goals of the WindSTAR Center are to: (1) conduct research that benefits its wind industry members; (2) bring together university and industry researchers to conduct basic and applied research on wind energy; (3) combine state-of-the-art capabilities and knowledge to execute projects relevant to industry partners; (4) train students in the advanced technologies that are important to industry partners and to have a pipeline of state-of-the-art talent flowing from academia to industry; (5) foster a community for networking, interactions, and collaboration; and (6) help to make wind energy widespread by lowering the levelized cost of energy through increases in performance, improved reliability, material components, and modeling capabilities, as well as reduced capital/operating expenditures of wind turbine systems.  During the course of the grant period, the WindSTAR Center has been able to make significant strides in achieving all of these goals. 

 

The WindSTAR Center has executed 50 research projects, 26 of these projects were led by PIs from UML while 24 were led by PIs from UTD. The research projects span topics including: (A) Composites and Blade Manufacturing; (B) Structural Health Monitoring and Non-destructive Inspection; (C) Wind Plant Modeling and Measurements; (D) Control Systems Wind Turbines and Wind Plants; (E) Energy Storage and Grid Integration; and (F) Foundation and Towers.  The current composition of the WindSTAR Center today includes 11 Full member and 3 Associate member companies that span a broad sector of the wind industry.  The key accomplishments of these research projects were disseminated in 22 journal papers (7 from UML and 15 from UTD), 31 conference papers (13 from UML and 18 from UTD) and resulted in 5 students obtaining their M.S degree (2/UML and 3/UTD) and six obtaining their Ph.D. degree (2/UML and 4/UTD).  Several of these students were hired by member companies and are working in the wind industry.  Advancements were made in the understanding of composites, material forming simulation tools, techniques for the detection of damage and defects in materials and blades, structural health monitoring of turbine foundations, leading edge erosion, control system algorithms for improved power production, and fluid/structure simulation tools for wind farms.  To date seven different software packages have been created and delivered to the Center’s members.

 

A patent was also granted at UML that pertains to wind turbine foundation monitoring.  The WindSTAR Center faculty and member companies were also awarded several other multi-million dollar wind energy related grants supported by NSF, DOE, ONR, and ARPA-E and the Center received several supplemental funding grants through the NSF REU and INTERN Programs.

 

The Center leadership has actively recruited new members every year and hosted two in person meetings every year with the exception of summer 2020 through spring 2021 during the COVID-19 pandemic, in which the meetings were held virtually.  Each meeting was very well organized and included a reception and keynote presentation.  The Center also executed a “WindSTAR Day” in which each of the project PIs provide webinars allowing the Center member companies to view them in real time as well as having them be recorded.  In 2020 the Center has also initiated a webinar series that provides information about a specific research topic of interest and has a broad audience (5000+) of wind industry members. 

 

Both undergraduate and graduate students have been exposed to scientific research. Many of these students have been involved in meetings with companies and have attended scientific conferences where they have made presentations.  The students have also written conference and journal papers with guidance from the faculty mentors.  At the K-12 level, students and teachers have been exposed to engineering and design of experiments and with wind energy seminars at a middle school.     Educational materials were produced and widely distributed through social media.  The Center has also has been involved in K-12 outreach via the KidWind Project and created educational materials in collaboration with Futurum.  The article was very well received with thousands of engagements across social media platforms (i.e. Twitter, Facebook, Pinterest, and Instagram).

 

A summary of Major Accomplishments are presented for the Center in the 2020 Annual Report for Public Release and can be found on the Center website: www.uml.edu/windstar
